summary: This is an email from an Assistant U.S. Attorney (AUSA) to Alex Acosta, the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida, providing an update on victim notification in the Epstein case. The AUSA reports contacting the attorney for a victim (Ms. [redacted]), who is paid for by Epstein, to ask where to send the victim notification letter, but declined to disclose the letter's contents.

persons.name: Alex Acosta
persons.role: U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida
persons.context: Recipient of the email update regarding victim notification procedures in the Epstein case.

persons.name: Ms. [Redacted]
persons.context: A victim in the Epstein case whose attorney is being contacted for notification purposes; her attorney is paid for by Epstein.

connections.description: Epstein is the accused perpetrator, and Ms. [Redacted] is identified as a victim in the case.
Epstein is paying for the legal representation of the victim's attorney, as stated in the document.
The attorney represents the victim Ms. [Redacted] in the Epstein case.

events.title: Victim Notification Update
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney contacts the attorney for a victim (paid by Epstein) to arrange for sending a victim notification letter, but refuses to disclose the letter's contents.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was paying for the legal representation of at least one of his alleged victims as of December 2007.
The U.S. Attorney's office was in the process of formally notifying victims in the Epstein case, with plans to send letters within a week.
Prosecutors were cautious in their communications with the victim's attorney, refusing to disclose the contents of the notification letter when asked.
